turn.text: Which he says two different times -- he says, first of all he received the presentence investigative report, on the said defendant by -- and received by the state defendant’s attorney of a copy of that portion there after which they are entitled and then he says and after carefully considering and waiting, waiving and reviewing the factual information contained in the said pre-sentence investigation, the undersigned concludes and determines that aggravating circumstances exist to whip itemized as under any sentences the defendant to death.
That’s pretty clear that he did rely on it, isn’t it?

turn.speaker: wallace_e_allbritton
turn.label: Mr. Wallace E. Allbritton
turn.text: Not in total, no sir.
That among other things, I can’t say that you relied on the confidential part of it and it doesn’t say so and what -- he just --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, but he suggested, that was in total think, Mr. Allbritton.
Just whether or not he took it into consideration --

turn.speaker: wallace_e_allbritton
turn.label: Mr. Wallace E. Allbritton
turn.text: Yes, he did take it.
That’s the purpose of it sir.
That’s the purpose.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You made it very expressly clear that he did so.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Your time is up Mr. Allbritton.

turn.speaker: wallace_e_allbritton
turn.label: Mr. Wallace E. Allbritton
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you.
Do you have anything further Mr. Livingston?

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: Yes Your Honor, may it please the Court.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You have a minute left.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: Thank you.
How many sir?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: One minute.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: As to Williams, Mr. Justice Stevens is exactly correct, that was the confrontation case.
It was not a disclosure case.
337 U.S. 244 describes how that information was disclosed in open court.
In addition Williams was a pre Furman case also decided obviously before the July 1976 capital cases.
As to the confidential problem, that can be controlled. Federal rule 32 controls, we are not here claiming that a constitutional right to be free from all out of court information.
But we are here saying that we are entitled to know what the judge is using.
If there’s a need to protect somebody.
If there is a need not to disclose, he can disclose that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Could I ask you, how could the pre-sentence report have influenced or affected the judge's finding that there was the aggravating circumstance of an especially atrocious crime.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: He could've affected it by knocking out the mitigating circumstances in which the jury --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I am getting to that, how about the aggravating circumstance?

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: That circumstance was in open court before both judge and jury.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So that you put that aside but do you think the pre-sentence report might be relevant to the establishing a mitigating circumstance.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: Or to the disregarding and mitigating circumstance which necessarily must have been --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I know but he found there were no mitigating circumstance.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: Correct.
And he found it by reading it, the same information differently than the jury did about the drinking and whatever and the only difference --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Suppose he had no pre-sentence investigation at all and he had disagreed with the jury, he wouldn’t have any complaint then or you’ll have a complaint but not this one.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: That would not be found upon the confidential report -- the undisclosed, unjustified, unexplained nondisclosure, the confidential portion, no sir, it would not be.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Or do you think there might be something in the pre-sentence report affected his judgment about their being a mitigating circumstance present or not.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: Sir, I believe that we’re being pushed into speculating as to what effect did his decision making process at this crucial stage and then by being forced to speculate takes out harmless error in any event.
That yes, we are having to guess and I think that’s the most likely operation there.
They caused him to disregard what the jury found to be mitigating.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are you familiar with the Florida Supreme Court decisions in the Songer against State and Swan against State.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Both of which were cited and presently approved in the one of the opinions in Proffitt and each of which approved the use of a presentence investigation report by the sentencing judge under the Florida system, didn’t they?

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: That’s correct Mr. Justice Stewart, neither of which addressed the confidential problem however.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Was it clear in each of those cases that there had been a disclosure to the defendant or his counsel of the contents of the pre-sentence investigation.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: In Songer, I am certain there was a disclosure of the non confidential portion but not the confidential portion.
To swan, I don’t have any present recollection as to that point?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Both of those decisions were implicitly approved, weren’t they in the footnote number 9, in one of the opinions in Proffitt.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, Signer expressly states that he receive a copy of the PSI and it doesn’t differentiate between the non confidential and the confidential part, yes.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: That’s correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, then you are mistaken.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: On what point sir?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In saying that they -- there was not a disclosure of the confidential portion of it in Songer.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: No sir.
The Songer -- it's outside the record.
In Songer, there was a confidential portion, there was a disclosed portion.
The defendant did not get the confidential portion.
The Florida Supreme Court decision addresses the area of the PSI in general but does not address itself to confidential versus disclosed.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Of course in Songer or Swan, in one of the cases at least the Florida Supreme Court set aside the death sentence.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: Had the Swan --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Swan.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: Songer is still under the sentence of death.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I think you said in your opening argument that -- were these case back before the jury you would object to the submission of the pre-sentence report to the jury.
Did I understand you correctly?

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: My understanding at the time of -- that point in the argument Mr. Chief Justice was the information as to the guilt deciding phase of the trial as being collateral incidence relevant to a crime.
If I were his trial counsel I think and the trial counsel would object to this collateral information coming on the guilty, not guilty phase, about the guilty trial.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: At that point, the guilt has been determined by the jury, why would that be excludable?

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: No sir, what I was about was -- if there is an effort to it, introduce it at the guilt determination.
The first half of the trial.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We were talking in your opening argument about the possibility of the case being before the sentencing jury after the determination of guilt and I understood you to say that if the case by some chance should get into that posture by virtue of any remand, you would object to the introduction of the report, at that stage, in the sentencing process?

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: Well, my answer may not be responsive, my understanding at the time of making that answer was related to the first half of the trial, it didn’t involve here.
But as to the sentencing jury, our position is that if the state is going to use, if the judge is going to use it to consider it, review it.
That the defendant should at least be entitled to notice of the general nature of it, so if they can't -- they may not be able to keep it up. They can rebut it, clarify it or explain it.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, if it went to the sentencing jury, you surely would have a copy of it.
It can't go to the jury without through you, through counsel.

turn.speaker: charles_h_livingston
turn.label: Mr. Charles H. Livingston
turn.text: Well, one would think the due process clause and the Sixth Amendment would keep it from going to the judge without going through us either under the circumstances of this case.
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
